metadata.subject: physics
dotPoints: interpret Einstein's prediction by showing that the total 'mass-energy' of an object is given by: Etot = Ek + E₀ = γmc² where E₀ = mc², and where kinetic energy can be calculated by: Ek = (γ − 1)mc²

apply the energy-mass relationship to mass conversion in the Sun, to positron-electron annihilation and to nuclear transformations in particle accelerators (details of the particular nuclear processes are not required)

rest_energy_formula.name: Rest Energy Formula
rest_energy_formula.correct: Rest energy equals mass multiplied by the speed of light squared. This is the energy equivalent of an object's mass when stationary.

E₀ = mc.fix: The formula is E₀ = mc². The c must be squared.
E₀ = mc.action: Check your formula sheet. Energy has units J = kg·m²/s², which requires c².

E₀ = ½mc².error: Confusing with classical kinetic energy formula.
E₀ = ½mc².fix: Rest energy has no ½ factor. That's for KE = ½mv².
E₀ = ½mc².action: Rest energy and kinetic energy are different formulas. Don't mix them.

E₀ = γmc².error: That's total energy, not rest energy.
E₀ = γmc².fix: Rest energy has no γ factor. E₀ = mc² applies when the object is at rest (γ = 1).
E₀ = γmc².action: Rest means stationary. When v = 0, γ = 1, so Etot = E₀.

persistent.gap: You're confusing rest energy with other energy formulas.
persistent.action: Write out all three: E₀ = mc², Etot = γmc², Ek = (γ−1)mc². Note which has γ and which doesn't.

rest_energy_meaning.name: Rest Energy Meaning
rest_energy_meaning.correct: Rest energy is the energy equivalent of an object's mass when stationary. It represents stored energy that can be released in nuclear reactions.

energy when moving.error: That's total energy, not rest energy.
energy when moving.fix: REST energy is measured when the object is at REST (stationary).
energy when moving.action: Think about the name: rest energy = energy at rest = when v = 0.

kinetic energy at rest.error: At rest, kinetic energy is zero, not mc².
kinetic energy at rest.fix: Rest energy is the mass-equivalent energy, separate from kinetic energy.
kinetic energy at rest.action: KE = 0 when v = 0. Rest energy exists even when not moving.

potential energy.error: Rest energy is not the same as potential energy.
potential energy.fix: Rest energy is mass converted to energy. Potential energy is due to position.
potential energy.action: E₀ = mc² relates mass to energy, not position to energy.

persistent.gap: You don't understand what rest energy represents.
persistent.action: Key insight: mass IS a form of energy. Rest energy is how much energy that mass equals.

total_energy_formula.name: Total Energy Formula
total_energy_formula.correct: Total relativistic energy equals the Lorentz factor times mass times c squared. It includes both rest energy and kinetic energy.

Etot = mc².fix: mc² is rest energy only. Total energy is γmc².
Etot = mc².action: When moving, γ > 1, so Etot > E₀. The γ accounts for motion.

Etot = ½γmc².error: No ½ factor in total energy.
Etot = ½γmc².fix: Etot = γmc² has no ½. The ½ appears only in classical KE.
Etot = ½γmc².action: Relativistic formulas don't use ½. That's a classical approximation.

Etot = (γ−1)mc².error: That's kinetic energy, not total energy.
Etot = (γ−1)mc².fix: Total = rest + kinetic. Etot = γmc², Ek = (γ−1)mc².
Etot = (γ−1)mc².action: Total energy includes rest energy. (γ−1)mc² excludes it.

persistent.gap: You're confusing total energy with its components.
persistent.action: Remember: Etot = Ek + E₀. So γmc² = (γ−1)mc² + mc². Verify by algebra.

total_energy_components.name: Total Energy Components
total_energy_components.correct: Total energy is the sum of kinetic energy and rest energy. At rest, total energy equals rest energy.

Etot = Ek − E₀.fix: Total = kinetic PLUS rest. Both contribute positively.
Etot = Ek − E₀.action: Energy is always positive. Adding two positive quantities.

Etot = Ek × E₀.fix: Etot = Ek + E₀. Energies add, they don't multiply.
Etot = Ek × E₀.action: Think about it: when v = 0, Ek = 0, so Etot = E₀. That only works with addition.

Etot = Ek only.fix: Even at rest, an object has energy E₀ = mc².
Etot = Ek only.action: Rest energy exists whether moving or not. It must be included.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how energy components combine.
persistent.action: Verify: γmc² = (γ−1)mc² + mc². Simplify the right side algebraically.

relativistic_ke_formula.name: Relativistic Kinetic Energy Formula
relativistic_ke_formula.correct: Relativistic kinetic energy equals (γ minus 1) times mc². This replaces ½mv² at high speeds.

Ek = γmc².error: That's total energy, not kinetic energy alone.
Ek = γmc².fix: Kinetic energy is (γ−1)mc². The −1 subtracts the rest energy.

Ek = ½mv².error: That's classical KE, only valid at low speeds.
Ek = ½mv².action: Classical formula fails above about 0.1c. Use relativistic formula.

Ek = ½γmv².error: Mixing classical and relativistic formulas incorrectly.
Ek = ½γmv².fix: The correct relativistic formula is Ek = (γ−1)mc², not a modified classical formula.
Ek = ½γmv².action: Don't try to 'fix' ½mv² by adding γ. Use the correct formula.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly applying the relativistic KE formula.
persistent.action: Derive it: Ek = Etot − E₀ = γmc² − mc² = (γ−1)mc². This shows why the formula works.

lorentz_factor_energy.name: Lorentz Factor in Energy
lorentz_factor_energy.correct: The Lorentz factor γ appears in relativistic energy formulas. As v approaches c, γ approaches infinity, so energy approaches infinity.

γ = √(1−v²/c²).error: Missing the 1 over. γ is the reciprocal of that.
γ = √(1−v²/c²).fix: γ = 1/√(1−v²/c²). The square root is in the denominator.
γ = √(1−v²/c²).action: When v = 0, γ = 1/√1 = 1. Check this with your formula.

γ = 1−v²/c².error: Missing the square root and reciprocal.
γ = 1−v²/c².fix: γ = 1/√(1−v²/c²). Don't forget the square root and the 1 over.
γ = 1−v²/c².action: Write out the full formula. Three parts: 1 over, square root, (1−v²/c²).

γ = v/c.fix: γ = 1/√(1−v²/c²). It's much more complex than v/c.
γ = v/c.action: Review the Lorentz factor derivation. It comes from time dilation.

persistent.gap: You haven't memorised the Lorentz factor formula.
persistent.action: γ = 1/√(1−v²/c²). Calculate γ for v = 0, 0.6c, 0.8c, 0.99c. See the pattern.

gamma_at_rest.name: Lorentz Factor at Rest
gamma_at_rest.correct: When an object is at rest (v = 0), the Lorentz factor equals 1. This means total energy equals rest energy.

γ = infinity.error: γ approaches infinity when v approaches c, not when v = 0.
γ = infinity.fix: At rest (v = 0), γ = 1. As v → c, γ → ∞.
γ = infinity.action: Think about limits: low speed → γ ≈ 1, high speed → γ → ∞.

γ = c.error: γ is dimensionless, c has units of speed.
γ = c.fix: γ has no units. At v = 0, γ = 1 (just the number 1).

persistent.gap: You don't understand the Lorentz factor's limiting behaviour.
persistent.action: Make a table: v = 0, 0.5c, 0.9c, 0.99c. Calculate γ for each. See the trend.

mass_energy_conservation.name: Mass-Energy Conservation
mass_energy_conservation.correct: Mass can be converted to energy and vice versa. The total mass-energy of an isolated system is conserved.

mass is always conserved separately.error: Mass can be converted to energy.
mass is always conserved separately.fix: In nuclear reactions, some mass becomes energy. Mass alone is not conserved.
mass is always conserved separately.action: Example: In the Sun, hydrogen mass is converted to helium mass plus energy.

energy is always conserved separately.error: Energy can come from mass conversion.
energy is always conserved separately.fix: Mass-energy is conserved together. Mass can become energy.
energy is always conserved separately.action: In annihilation, all mass becomes energy. Total mass-energy is constant.

mass and energy are unrelated.fix: Mass IS a form of energy. They can convert into each other.
mass and energy are unrelated.action: The whole point of E = mc² is that mass and energy are equivalent.

persistent.action: Key insight: mass is concentrated energy. 1 kg of mass = 9×10¹⁶ J of energy.

mass_defect.name: Mass Defect
mass_defect.correct: Mass defect is the difference between the mass of reactants and products. This missing mass is converted to energy.

Δm = mproducts − mreactants.error: Reversed order for reactions that release energy.
Δm = mproducts − mreactants.fix: For energy release, reactants have more mass. Δm = mreactants − mproducts.
Δm = mproducts − mreactants.action: In fusion, products are lighter. The lost mass becomes energy.

mass defect is an error.error: It's not an error—it's real mass converted to energy.
mass defect is an error.fix: Mass defect is the mass that becomes energy in nuclear reactions.
mass defect is an error.action: The 'missing' mass isn't lost. It's converted to energy via E = Δmc².

mass defect is always zero.fix: Fusion and fission have measurable mass defects that produce energy.
mass defect is always zero.action: Calculate: Sun converts ~4 million tonnes of mass to energy per second.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how mass converts to energy.
persistent.action: Work through a fusion example: find masses before/after, calculate Δm, then E = Δmc².

fusion_sun.name: Fusion in the Sun
fusion_sun.correct: In the Sun, hydrogen nuclei fuse to form helium. The products have less mass than the reactants, and the mass difference becomes energy.

fission occurs in the Sun.error: The Sun uses fusion, not fission.
fission occurs in the Sun.fix: Fusion joins small nuclei (hydrogen). Fission splits large nuclei (uranium).
fission occurs in the Sun.action: Stars use fusion. Nuclear reactors typically use fission.

helium has more mass than hydrogen.error: The helium product has less mass than the hydrogen reactants.
helium has more mass than hydrogen.fix: Mass is lost in fusion. 4 hydrogen nuclei → 1 helium + energy.
helium has more mass than hydrogen.action: The mass defect in solar fusion is about 0.7% of the original mass.

no mass is lost.error: Mass is definitely converted to energy.
no mass is lost.fix: The Sun loses ~4 million tonnes of mass per second to produce light.
no mass is lost.action: Calculate: Sun's power output ÷ c² = mass loss rate.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how the Sun produces energy.
persistent.action: Research the proton-proton chain. Trace the mass through each step.

positron_electron_annihilation.name: Positron-Electron Annihilation
positron_electron_annihilation.correct: When a positron meets an electron, they annihilate completely, converting all their mass to energy as two gamma rays.

only one gamma ray is produced.error: Conservation of momentum requires two gamma rays.
only one gamma ray is produced.fix: Two gamma rays travelling in opposite directions conserves momentum.
only one gamma ray is produced.action: If one gamma ray, what happens to momentum? It must be conserved.

some mass remains.error: In annihilation, ALL mass converts to energy.
some mass remains.fix: Both particles disappear completely. Only gamma rays remain.
some mass remains.action: Annihilation = complete destruction. Mass → energy entirely.

only the positron is destroyed.fix: Positron and electron both annihilate. Neither survives.
only the positron is destroyed.action: It's mutual annihilation. Both particles cease to exist.

persistent.action: Calculate: 2 × electron mass × c² = total energy of gamma rays.

annihilation_energy.name: Annihilation Energy Calculation
annihilation_energy.correct: The energy released in electron-positron annihilation equals twice the electron rest mass times c² (both particles contribute).

E = mₑc².fix: Both electron AND positron mass convert. E = 2mₑc².
E = mₑc².action: Two particles annihilate, so total mass = 2mₑ.

E = mₑc² + ½mₑv².error: Mixing rest energy with classical kinetic energy.
E = mₑc² + ½mₑv².fix: For low-speed annihilation, E ≈ 2mₑc². KE is negligible.
E = mₑc² + ½mₑv².action: At low speeds, rest energy dominates. Ignore classical KE.

E = ½ × 2mₑc².error: No ½ factor in mass-energy conversion.
E = ½ × 2mₑc².fix: E = Δmc². No ½ factor appears.
E = ½ × 2mₑc².action: Don't confuse with KE = ½mv². Different formula entirely.

persistent.gap: You're making calculation errors in annihilation problems.

particle_accelerators.name: Particle Accelerators
particle_accelerators.correct: Particle accelerators give particles very high kinetic energy. When particles collide, this energy can create new massive particles.

accelerators only speed up particles.error: They also create new particles from collision energy.
accelerators only speed up particles.fix: High-energy collisions can produce new particles with mass.
accelerators only speed up particles.action: E = mc² works both ways: energy can become mass.

new particles come from splitting old on.error: New particles can be created from pure energy.
new particles come from splitting old on.fix: Kinetic energy converts to mass of new particles.
new particles come from splitting old on.action: Products can have MORE total mass than reactants if enough KE is supplied.

mass is always conserved in collisions.fix: Mass-energy is conserved. High KE can create new massive particles.
mass is always conserved in collisions.action: Higgs boson has huge mass, created from collision energy.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how accelerators create particles.
persistent.action: Research CERN. How was the Higgs boson discovered? Where did its mass come from?

speed_limit_energy.name: Speed Limit and Infinite Energy
speed_limit_energy.correct: As an object approaches the speed of light, its total energy approaches infinity. This explains why massive objects cannot reach c.

energy stays finite.error: Energy approaches infinity as v approaches c.
energy stays finite.fix: γ → ∞ as v → c, so Etot = γmc² → ∞.
energy stays finite.action: Calculate γ for v = 0.99c, 0.999c, 0.9999c. Watch it grow.

objects can reach c with enough energy.fix: No finite amount of energy can accelerate a mass to c.
objects can reach c with enough energy.action: This is why c is the universal speed limit for massive objects.

only applies to large objects.error: Applies to ANY object with mass, no matter how small.
only applies to large objects.fix: Even electrons cannot reach c. They can get very close but never reach it.
only applies to large objects.action: At CERN, particles reach 0.999999991c but never quite c.

persistent.gap: You don't understand why c is unreachable.
persistent.action: Plot Etot vs v from 0 to c. See how energy shoots to infinity near c.

classical_vs_relativistic.name: Classical vs Relativistic KE
classical_vs_relativistic.correct: Classical KE (½mv²) is only accurate at low speeds. At high speeds, relativistic KE (γ−1)mc² gives dramatically higher values.

both formulas give the same answer.error: They diverge significantly at high speeds.
both formulas give the same answer.fix: At v = 0.9c, relativistic KE is about 2.3× the classical prediction.
both formulas give the same answer.action: Calculate both for v = 0.9c and compare.

classical formula is always wrong.error: Classical formula is a good approximation at low speeds.
classical formula is always wrong.fix: Below ~0.1c, ½mv² is accurate enough for most purposes.
classical formula is always wrong.action: At everyday speeds, the difference is negligible.

use classical formula for electrons.error: Electrons in accelerators move at relativistic speeds.
use classical formula for electrons.fix: Any particle moving above ~0.1c needs relativistic formulas.
use classical formula for electrons.action: Check the speed first. If v > 0.1c, use relativistic formulas.

persistent.gap: You don't know when to use which formula.
persistent.action: Rule: v < 0.1c → classical OK. v > 0.1c → use relativistic.

rest_energy.title: Understanding Rest Energy
rest_energy.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of rest energy and its relationship to mass.

sentences.text: Einstein's equation E₀ = {{d1}} shows that mass and energy are {{d2}}. Even a stationary object has energy due to its {{d3}}.

d1.tooltip: What is the correct formula for rest energy?

d2.tooltip: What relationship does E = mc² establish?

d3.tooltip: What property gives an object rest energy?

sentences.text: Rest energy is called 'rest' energy because it applies when the object is {{d4}}. In this case, the Lorentz factor γ equals {{d5}}, so Etot = E₀.

d4.tooltip: What does 'rest' mean in rest energy?

sentences.text: The speed of light c in E₀ = mc² must be {{d6}} in the formula. Using SI units, c = {{d7}} m/s.

d6.tooltip: What power of c appears in E₀ = mc²?

d7.tooltip: What is the value of c in metres per second?

total_energy.title: Understanding Total Relativistic Energy
total_energy.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of total energy for moving objects.

sentences.text: The total mass-energy of a moving object is given by Etot = {{d1}}. The symbol γ represents the {{d2}}, which depends on the object's {{d3}}.

d1.tooltip: What is the formula for total relativistic energy?

d3.tooltip: What variable determines the value of γ?

sentences.text: Total energy can be written as Etot = Ek + E₀, meaning total energy is the {{d4}} of kinetic energy and rest energy. When the object is at rest, Etot equals {{d5}}.

d4.tooltip: How do Ek and E₀ combine to give Etot?

d5.tooltip: When v = 0, what is Ek? So what does Etot equal?

sentences.text: As an object's speed approaches the speed of light, γ approaches {{d6}}, which means total energy approaches {{d7}}. This explains why massive objects {{d8}} reach the speed of light.

d6.tooltip: What happens to 1/√(1−v²/c²) as v → c?

d7.tooltip: If γ → ∞, what happens to γmc²?

d8.tooltip: Is it possible to supply infinite energy?

kinetic_energy.title: Understanding Relativistic Kinetic Energy
kinetic_energy.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of kinetic energy at relativistic speeds.

sentences.text: Relativistic kinetic energy is calculated using Ek = {{d1}}. This formula replaces the classical formula Ek = {{d2}} at high speeds.

d1.tooltip: What is the relativistic kinetic energy formula?

d2.tooltip: What is the classical kinetic energy formula?

sentences.text: The factor (γ−1) in the kinetic energy formula ensures that when v = 0, kinetic energy equals {{d3}}. This is because when v = 0, γ = {{d4}}, so (γ−1) = {{d5}}.

d3.tooltip: What is an object's kinetic energy when stationary?

sentences.text: At relativistic speeds, the classical formula {{d6}} the actual kinetic energy. The relativistic formula becomes necessary when speeds exceed about {{d7}} of the speed of light.

d6.tooltip: Does ½mv² give too much or too little at high speeds?

d7.tooltip: At what approximate speed do relativistic effects become significant?

applications.title: Applications of Mass-Energy Equivalence
applications.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of mass-energy applications.

sentences.text: In nuclear reactions, the total mass-energy is {{d1}}. When energy is released, the products have {{d2}} total mass than the reactants. This mass difference is called the {{d3}}.

d1.tooltip: What happens to total mass-energy in an isolated system?

d2.tooltip: Where does the released energy come from?

d3.tooltip: What is the name for missing mass in nuclear reactions?

sentences.text: In the Sun, {{d4}} nuclei fuse to form {{d5}}. The mass of the products is less than the mass of the reactants, and this mass difference is converted to {{d6}}.

d4.tooltip: What is the lightest element that fuels the Sun?

d5.tooltip: What element is produced when hydrogen nuclei fuse?

d6.tooltip: What does the missing mass become?

sentences.text: When a positron meets an electron, they {{d7}}, converting all their mass to {{d8}}. Two gamma rays are produced travelling in {{d9}} directions.

d7.tooltip: What happens when matter meets antimatter?

d8.tooltip: What form does the mass take after annihilation?

d9.tooltip: How must the gamma rays travel to conserve momentum?

rest_energy.title: Applying Rest Energy Concepts
rest_energy.instructions: Apply your understanding of rest energy to these scenarios.

sentences.text: An electron has a rest mass of 9.1 × 10⁻³¹ kg. To calculate its rest energy, we use E₀ = mc², giving E₀ = 9.1 × 10⁻³¹ × (3 × 10⁸)² = {{d1}} J. This can also be expressed as {{d2}} MeV.

d2.tooltip: Convert to eV, then to MeV. 1 eV = 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ J.

sentences.text: If 1 kg of mass could be entirely converted to energy, it would release E = 1 × (3 × 10⁸)² = {{d3}} J. This enormous value explains why nuclear weapons release so much energy from such {{d4}} amounts of converted mass.

d4.tooltip: Is c² large or small? What does that imply about the mass needed?

sentences.text: Rest energy exists independently of an object's {{d5}}. A book on a shelf has the same rest energy as the same book falling, because rest energy depends only on {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: What does 'rest' imply about what doesn't matter?

d6.tooltip: Look at the formula E₀ = mc². What variables appear?

total_energy.title: Applying Total Energy Concepts
total_energy.instructions: Apply your understanding of total relativistic energy to these scenarios.

sentences.text: A proton with mass 1.67 × 10⁻²⁷ kg travels at a speed where γ = 2. Its total energy is Etot = γmc² = 2 × 1.67 × 10⁻²⁷ × (3 × 10⁸)² = {{d1}} J. This is {{d2}} its rest energy.
For the same proton, its kinetic energy is Ek = Etot − E₀ = (γ−1)mc² = (2−1) × 1.67 × 10⁻²⁷ × (3 × 10⁸)² = {{d3}} J. At this speed, the kinetic energy equals the {{d4}} energy.

d4.tooltip: When γ = 2: Etot = 2E₀ and Ek = E₀. What does Ek equal?

sentences.text: The Lorentz factor γ = 1/√(1−v²/c²). For v = 0.6c, we get γ = 1/√(1−0.36) = 1/√0.64 = {{d5}}. This means total energy is {{d6}} times the rest energy.

kinetic_energy.title: Applying Relativistic Kinetic Energy
kinetic_energy.instructions: Apply your understanding of relativistic kinetic energy to these calculations.

sentences.text: Using classical physics, a proton at 0.9c would have KE = ½ × 1.67 × 10⁻²⁷ × (0.9 × 3 × 10⁸)² = 6.1 × 10⁻¹¹ J. Using relativistic physics with γ = 2.29, we get KE = {{d1}} J. The classical value {{d2}} the true kinetic energy.

At CERN, protons reach speeds of 0.999999991c, giving γ ≈ 7500. The kinetic energy is then approximately {{d3}} times the rest energy. This shows why reaching the speed of light would require {{d4}} energy.

d4.tooltip: As v → c, γ → ∞, so Ek → ∞.

sentences.text: An electron has kinetic energy equal to its rest energy. Using Ek = (γ−1)mc², we find (γ−1) = {{d5}}, so γ = {{d6}}. This electron is travelling at approximately 0.866c.

d5.tooltip: If Ek = E₀, then (γ−1)mc² = mc², so (γ−1) = ?

applications.title: Applying Mass-Energy to Real Scenarios
applications.instructions: Apply mass-energy concepts to these real-world applications.

sentences.text: The Sun converts approximately 4 × 10⁹ kg of mass to energy every second. Using E = mc², this equals {{d1}} W of power. The Sun has been producing this energy for about {{d2}} billion years.

d2.tooltip: How old is our solar system?

sentences.text: In a PET scan, a positron from a radioactive tracer meets a {{d3}} in the patient's body. The resulting annihilation produces two gamma rays, each with energy E = mₑc² = {{d4}} J.

d3.tooltip: What particle is the antimatter partner of a positron?

d4.tooltip: Each gamma ray gets energy from one particle's mass.

sentences.text: In particle accelerators, two protons colliding at high speed can create new particles. The total mass of products can be {{d5}} than the original protons' mass because the collision {{d6}} is converted to mass.

d5.tooltip: Energy can become mass. If there's extra energy, can extra mass be created?

d6.tooltip: What form of energy do the fast-moving protons have?

rest_energy.title: Mastering Rest Energy Concepts
rest_energy.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of rest energy by addressing these complex scenarios and common misconceptions.

sentences.text: A common misconception is that E = mc² only applies to nuclear reactions. In reality, the equation applies to {{d1}} matter. A hot cup of coffee has {{d2}} rest mass than a cold cup because of its thermal energy, though this difference is immeasurably {{d3}}.

d1.tooltip: Does mass-energy equivalence have restrictions on what it applies to?

d2.tooltip: Thermal energy contributes to mass. Hot = more energy = more mass.

d3.tooltip: c² is huge, so mass change from everyday energy is tiny.

sentences.text: The formula E₀ = mc² shows that c² acts as a {{d4}} between mass and energy. Because c² = 9 × 10¹⁶ m²/s², a small mass corresponds to a {{d5}} amount of energy. This explains why the mass defect in nuclear reactions is {{d6}} compared to the energy released.

d4.tooltip: What role does c² play in relating E and m?

d5.tooltip: If the conversion factor is huge, what does that mean for E vs m?

d6.tooltip: E = mc² means large E from small m.

sentences.text: Students sometimes confuse E₀ = mc² with Etot = γmc². The key difference is that E₀ applies only when γ = {{d7}}, meaning the object is {{d8}}. Total energy Etot {{d9}} includes rest energy.

d9.tooltip: Etot = Ek + E₀. Is E₀ always part of Etot?

total_energy.title: Mastering Total Energy Concepts
total_energy.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of total relativistic energy through these advanced scenarios.

sentences.text: The relationship Etot = Ek + E₀ can be verified algebraically: γmc² = (γ−1)mc² + mc². Expanding the right side gives {{d1}} + mc² = {{d2}}, confirming the relationship.

A photon has zero rest mass, so its rest energy is {{d3}}. However, a photon still has total energy E = pc = hf. This shows that for massless particles, {{d4}} energy equals total energy, not rest energy.

d3.tooltip: If m = 0, what is E₀ = mc²?

d4.tooltip: If E₀ = 0 but Etot ≠ 0, what makes up Etot?

sentences.text: An electron with γ = 10 has total energy {{d5}} times its rest energy. Its kinetic energy is {{d6}} times its rest energy. This shows that at high γ, most of the total energy is {{d7}} energy.

d7.tooltip: If Ek/E₀ = 9, kinetic energy is 9× rest energy. Which dominates?

kinetic_energy.title: Mastering Relativistic Kinetic Energy
kinetic_energy.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of relativistic kinetic energy through these challenging scenarios.

sentences.text: At low speeds, (γ−1) ≈ {{d1}} for small v, making Ek ≈ ½mv². This shows the classical formula is a {{d2}} of the relativistic formula. The approximation breaks down when v exceeds about {{d3}}.

d1.tooltip: Taylor expansion of γ−1 for small v.

d2.tooltip: Classical physics is contained within relativistic physics.

d3.tooltip: At what speed do relativistic corrections become significant?

sentences.text: Doubling a particle's speed from 0.4c to 0.8c does {{d4}} double its kinetic energy. At 0.4c, γ ≈ 1.09, so Ek ≈ 0.09mc². At 0.8c, γ ≈ 1.67, so Ek ≈ {{d5}}. The ratio is approximately {{d6}}.

d4.tooltip: Is relativistic KE proportional to v²?

sentences.text: A particle accelerator increases a proton's energy from 938 MeV (rest energy) to 7 TeV. The Lorentz factor γ = Etot/E₀ = {{d7}}. This means the proton's kinetic energy is approximately {{d8}} times its rest energy, demonstrating that accelerators put {{d9}} energy into kinetic energy than into creating additional mass.

d9.tooltip: If Ek >> E₀, where does most energy go?

applications.title: Mastering Mass-Energy Applications
applications.instructions: Demonstrate mastery by synthesising mass-energy concepts across multiple applications.

sentences.text: In both fusion and fission, the products have {{d1}} mass than the reactants. The key difference is that fusion joins {{d2}} nuclei while fission splits {{d3}} nuclei. Both processes release energy because the products are more tightly bound.

d1.tooltip: Energy release requires mass conversion to energy.

d2.tooltip: Fusion joins small nuclei. What type are they?

d3.tooltip: Fission splits large nuclei. What type are they?

sentences.text: High-energy electron-positron annihilation differs from low-energy annihilation because the particles' {{d4}} must also be accounted for. At high speeds, the gamma rays have {{d5}} energy than at low speeds, and additional particles {{d6}} be created.

d4.tooltip: What additional energy do fast-moving particles have?

d5.tooltip: More input energy = more output energy.

d6.tooltip: If there's enough energy, can it become mass?

sentences.text: The discovery of the Higgs boson at CERN required collisions with enough energy to create its rest mass of 125 GeV/c². The energy came from the {{d7}} of the colliding protons. This demonstrates that E = mc² works {{d8}}: not only does mass convert to energy, but energy can also convert to {{d9}}.

d8.tooltip: Can energy become mass as well as mass becoming energy?

d9.tooltip: If energy can become mass, what does collision energy become?
